Authors: Murphy, G. H.; Chiu, P.; Triantafyllopoulou, P.; Barnoux, M.; Blake, E.; Cooke, J.; Forrester-Jones, R. V. E.; Gore, N. J.; Beecham, J. K.
Article Title: Offenders with intellectual disabilities in prison: what happens when they leave?
Abstract: BackgroundPeople with intellectual disabilities, if convicted of offences, may be sentenced to prison, but little is known about their life when they are released.MethodThis study followed up men with intellectual disabilities who were leaving prisons in England.ResultsThe men were hard to contact, but 38 men were interviewed, on average 10weeks after leaving prison. The men were living in a variety of situations and often were very under-occupied, with limited social networks. A total of 70% were above the clinical cut-off for anxiety, and 59.5% were above the clinical cut-off for depression. The men were receiving little support in the community, and many had been reinterviewed by police.ConclusionsCommunity teams need to provide better support to this very vulnerable group.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study does not directly address employment and focuses on the post-release life of men with intellectual disabilities in prison, rather than their employment outcomes.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not address employment or labor outcomes and the population is offenders with intellectual disabilities rather than people with mental health disorders.
